content: I can't say why the option to choose the calendar is missing, but TB should save invitations to the calendar that is currently selected on the left pane of the Calendar tab.
creator: sfhowes

content: On another computer with the same OS and thunderbird version I have the same exact problem, so it isn't isolated to one installation. On the second computer, the only solution I have found to force thunderbird to let me choose which calendar to use is to make the new calendar I just added read only. If this is the case, I can choose among my other calendars. I also tried selecting the calendar I want the invitation to go to in the left pane of the calendar tab before accepting the invitation, but if the new calendar is not read-only, invitations still go to that calendar regardless. I also tried turning on and off read-only and turning on and off the email associated with the new calendar, but neither of these changed the outcome. Read only is the only solution I have found.
creator: dmkaplan20001

content: I think I have found the magic that seems to make it allow me to choose calendars even when the new calendar is not read only, but this is definitely odd behavior. If I associated the new calendar with my google email address and not my work address and then accept an invitation, it let's me choose a calendar. If I do this once, I can then associate the new calendar with my work email again and the option to select calendars still appears when I accept an invitation. This seems to work for me so I am documenting it here, but this is definitely not normal behavior.
creator: dmkaplan20001

content: I've never seen this behaviour before, where the read status affects the ability to choose the target calendar for invitations. If this happened to me, and the workarounds were unsatisfactory, I'd be inclined to create a new test profile (Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles), add the accounts and calendars, making sure each is read/write capable, and associated with the correct email account. Then, see if they work properly with invitations. This might be a lot faster and more effective than trying to debug the current profile.
creator: sfhowes

content: I appreciate the suggestion, but to my ears this sounds like quite a bit of work. After rebooting, it seems like it goes back to automatically saving to the wrong calendar. For the time being I am using the workaround of making the calendar read-only unless I specifically need to add an event to that calendar. Not particularly efficient, but a workable solution. If there was some way to export diagnostic information to try to find the origin of the problem, I would be happy to do that.
creator: dmkaplan20001

content:
Port should be 587. Connection security should be STARTTLS. User name should be the whole e-mail address. Authentication method should be normal password.

And you must use an app-specific password from Apple instead of your regular password. Are you using one?
creator: mozilla98

content: Also: based on my settings, the server name should have the same domain as the e-mail address, e.g., an e-mail address at me.com should use the smtp.mail.me.com server.

content:
1. Change the default setting to unthreaded for new folders in Settings > Appearance.
  2. Change one of the existing folders in View > Sort by > Unthreaded.
  3. Copy that setting to other existing folders by clicking on the icon on the far right of the column headings in table view and choosing "Copy current view to".

creator: davidsk

content:
I don't understand your question. If you're trying to change your Mozilla account password, here is an article telling you how.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-change-or-reset-your-mozilla-account-password

If you are trying to change the password for your email account, you can't do that from within Thunderbird - you have to go to your email provider's web site to do that. You can then, knowing your new password, change the stored password within Thunderbird to agree with it. Here's an article describing how to edit saved passwords:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb

If you need more help, please be more specific as to what your intention is and we can give you some more details. If you're looking to change your email password, tell us what version of Thunderbird you're using, what your operating system is, and who your email provider is.

content:
Non sono a conoscenza di bug per cui la password principale si attivi senza l'intervento dell'utente (anche perché bisogna inserirla la password...). Ti suggerisco di controllare che altri non possano accedere al tuo PC (sia localmente che da remoto).

Per quanto riguarda la procedura, una volta aperta la console degli errori devi copiare nell'ultima riga in basso tutta la seguente espressione openDialog("chrome://pippki/content/resetpassword.xhtml") e premere Invio

Si aprirà una nuova finestra di dialogo chiamata Rimozione della password principale. Se in questa finestra premi il pulsante [Reimposta] la password principale verrà rimossa e i login cancellati. Assicurati che questa finestra non rimanga dietro alle altre finestre aperte e quindi non sia visibile in primo piano.

content:
Mi spiace ma non c'è un metodo alternativo per rimuovere la password principale.

Possiamo solo provare ad aggirare il problema.

  1. anzitutto quando compare la richiesta di password, fai click sul pulsante [Annulla]; in questo modo dovresti se non altro poter consultare la posta già scaricata in passato
  2. fai poi una copia di backup del tuo profilo attuale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo

I passi successivi dipendono dal tipo di account che hai configurato su Thunderbird. Dovresti quindi controllare se stai usando il protocollo POP3 o IMAP -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/differenze-imap-pop3

creator: lucarossi1471

content:
Con IMAP dovrebbe essere tutto relativamente semplice.

  1. Crea un nuovo profilo Thunderbird come spiegato qui https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/utilizzare-piu-profili#w_creare-un-profilo Tieni conto che nelle ultime versioni l'interfaccia potrebbe essere un po' diversa. Un profilo è uno spazio separato in cui vengono memorizzate le impostazioni e le email gestite da Thunderbird. Il nuovo profilo si affianca a quello attuale e sarai comunque in grado di passare dall’uno all'altro finché non deciderai eventualmente di eliminare quello vecchio.
  2. Avvia Thunderbird con il nuovo profilo e configura normalmente i tuoi account di posta usando sempre il protocollo IMAP.
  3. Attendi che Thunderbird sincronizzi la posta con i vari server dei tuoi account. Se hai molta posta potrebbe volerci un po' di tempo.

Alla fine dovresti riavere tutto funzionante e sincronizzato. A questo punto, ma non è necessario, potresti anche eliminare il vecchio profilo.

content:
My suggestion:

  1. keep IMAP to ensure all remains accessible from wherever
  2. for archiving, I suggest this:
    • set up local folder for each archive
    • select and copy messages to be archived and removed from server to the new local folder
    • check to verify that you have both content and header of the new archive in the new folder
    • now, you can delete from server
    • repeat the above four steps for each archive.

Specifically, do not use the thunderbird archive feature. use your own archiving setup, as suggested above. AND, be religious on backups.
creator: davidsk

content:
To be clear, you are recommending AGAINST the archive process described in the link below, even if I configure it to archive to a local folder? https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/archived-messages

Any thoughts on using Google Takeout or not?

Thank you!
creator: operaflute

content: That's right; although there may be better approaches than mine, not losing messages is my top priority, and by manually controlling it, you avoid abdicating it to Thunderbird. That works ok for POP, but IMAP is a different animal. I confess to total ignorance on google takeout. Also, my approach is my personal strategy; some may say I am wrong, but I see too many people losing messages from IMAP downloads where they end up with just the headers. ..
creator: davidsk

content: Do the changes work until you restart Thunderbird? I that is happening, then something is interrupting the shutdown. This can be caused by an anti-virus or VPN, normally. If you look at the profile folder and seen more than one prefs.js file, that is a big clue.

content: It will be easier, faster and more productive to create a new profile (Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles) and add your accounts. (Disable the account hub in Settings/General and add from ≡ - New Account - Email.) The original profile is unaffected, and if the new one works properly, you can transfer address books, local mail etc. from the old to the new. Do this with Kaspersky temporarily removed (not disabled) and the VPN disabled.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Add the accounts one-by-one and test them for saving changes. Install add-ons once all accounts are working. Copy abook.sqlite and history.sqlite from the old profile to the new; other sqlite address books can be imported from Tools/Import. Copy the mbox files from Mail/<popserver> and Mail/Local Folders in the old to Mail/Local Folders in the new.

I recommend not to copy prefs.js to avoid possible corrupted or obsolete entries.

content:
Hi Bianca,

The first time, did you re-organize and rename in Thunderbird or in the file system? I would think that doing it within Thunderbird is safer.

If you repaired the folder, then the folder is not inaccessible from Thunderbird. So what are the symptoms of the problem?

Would you please post screen images of 1) the BSW files in the file system and 2) Your local folders in Thunderbird, including BSW?

Unless your answers and screen images hold some surprises, one approach is to close Thunderbird, move the BSW files out of your profile to a working area such as your desktop, open Thunderbird, and use the add-on ImportExportToolsNG to import the BSW mbox file.

If that doesn't work, restore from back-up.

Did you do all that and when you tried to import the file using the add-on, no messages were imported? Did you right click on your local folders account and use the menu for ImportExportToolsNG there?

content: Can I assume this is a Gmail account? If so, the "All Mail" folder includes literally all mail, including the Trash folder. If you look in the Inbox folder you should see them gone, and you should find them in the "Trash" where you can permanently delete them if you want. It's recommended that you unsubscribe from the "All Mail" folder to avoid being misled.

creator: rednoise

content:
I fixed my problem by going to Thunderbird menu item Tools | Settings | General | System Integration and make sure the "Always check to see if Thunderbird is the default mail client on startup" is checked, and click the "Check Now" button. You might need to log out and back on, though I didn't need to.

Thunderbird has been acting like the default email program in all aspects that I noticed, but the option was unchecked. Maybe a Windows update did that?
creator: rednoise
